abstract.text: Test the identity of executable code on disk and in running processes.

legalNotices.copyright: Copyright © 2025 Apple Inc. All rights reserved.

inlineContent.text: Code that is cryptographically signed carries tamper-proof statements about its identity in its code signature.
Construct tests to distinguish different code files using the lightweight code requirement domain-specific language (DSL).
Use the tests to distinguish code files on disk, running processes, and processes that the operating system launches.
Code files on disk include:
Executable binaries
Dynamic or static libraries
Frameworks
Loadable bundles

content.text: Define tests of signed code properties

inlineContent.text: The keywords you use to test code properties in the lightweight code requirement DSL are:
Tests whether the code’s code directory hash matches a specific value, or is in a list of allowed values. For more information about code directory hashes, see
Tests whether the executable for a running process has particular flags, defined in
, set in its code signature.
Tests whether the code on disk has particular flags, defined in
, set in its code signature.
Tests whether the executable has a particular entitlement, optionally with a given value.
Tests whether the hash of the executable’s
file (or embedded

, for a command-line tool) matches a specific value, or is in a list of allowed values. Depending on the code signature version, the hash uses the SHA-1 or SHA-256 algorithm. Test whether the hash is in a list that contains both versions.
Tests whether the process is the initial process in the operating system, that is,
whether the executable is a main binary. A main binary has a code signature version of at least
and an executable segment with the
flag set.
Tests whether the code is on a volume covered by System Integrity Protection (SIP).
Tests whether the code targets a particular platform, for example iOS. The list of allowed values is defined in

Tests whether the code’s signing identifier matches a specific value, or is in a list of allowed values. The signing identifier is a string that’s typically the bundle identifier for a code bundle, for example an app, and has a similar structure for other code, for example, a command-line tool.
Tests whether the team identifier of the developer team that signed the code matches a specific value, or is in a list of allowed values.
Tests whether the team identifier of the developer team that signed the code for a running process matches the team identifier for the current process.
Tests whether the code is signed for a specific category, or is in a list of allowed categories. The list of values is defined in
For code signed by an organization or individual other than Apple, the code’s identity is specified by its
, and
The lightweight code requirement DSL provides operators that you use to build up complex requirements from individual tests. For example, the operators to construct on-disk code requirements are:
if one or more of its arguments is
if all of its arguments are
if each of its arguments is
if any of its arguments is
and
provide similar operators for building process code requirements and launch requirements.
The
and
operators simplify their inputs as follows:
An operator with a single constraint as its argument replaces itself with the direct evaluation of the given constraint.
If any of the arguments to an
operator are themselves
operators, the arguments to both are merged into a single set of constraints evaluated by the top-level
operator.
If any of the arguments to an
operator are themselves
operators, the arguments to both are merged into a single set of constraints evaluated by the top-level
operator.
Both
and
throw an error if the simplification results in the same constraint appearing twice in the arguments for one operator, for example, if an
operator contains two tests of
constraints.
The exception to this simplification rule is that multiple
tests can appear in the arguments for one operator.

content.text: Restrict the executables you launch as new processes

inlineContent.text: Create a

on a

If the executable specified in the process’s
satisfies the launch requirement, the kernel launches the process; otherwise,
throws an error.

You can also encode your requirements as launch constraints in property list files that you embed in your executable’s code signature to restrict which processes can launch your executable and which dynamic libraries your process can load.
For more information, see

abstract.text: Test the identity of executable code on disk and in running processes.
A constraint that matches the hash of a code directory of a code file or of a running or launching process.
Error types that can be thrown from lightweight code requirement routines.
A constraint that tests values in the entitlements dictionary associated with a process or code file.
A constraint that tests the specified hash against the Information property list hash stored in the code signature of the process or code file.
A constraint that tests whether a process is the operating system’s initial process.
A constraint that tests whether a code file is a main binary.
A constraint that tests whether a code file or process is on a volume protected by System Integrity Protection (SIP).
A lightweight code requirement that you use to evaluate the executable for a launching process.
A protocol to which a lightweight code requirement constraint conforms if you can use it in launch code requirements.
A custom parameter attribute that constructs launch constraints from closures.
A lightweight code requirement that you use to evaluate a code file on disk.
Create a
that requires matching all of the provided constraints.
Create a
that requires matching any of the provided constraints.
A constraint that tests the code-signing flags of a code file on disk.
Code signing flags that can be set on code on disk.
A protocol to which a lightweight code requirement constraint conforms if you can use it in on-disk code requirements.
A custom parameter attribute that constructs on-disk constraints from closures.
A constraint that tests whether a code file or running process targets a given platform.
Supported Platform Types for a process
A lightweight code requirement that you use to evaluate a running process.
A constraint that matches the current code-signing flags of a process.
Code signing flags that can be set on a process
A protocol to which a lightweight code requirement constraint conforms if you can use it in process code requirements.
A custom parameter attribute that constructs process constraints from closures.
Checks whether code on disk satisfies a lightweight code requirement.
Checks whether the code associated with a running process satisfies a lightweight code requirement.
Checks whether static code on disk satisfies a lightweight code requirement.
Tests whether a task’s executable satisfies a lightweight code requirement.
A constraint that tests whether the provided signing identifier matches the signature attached to the code.
A constraint that tests whether the provided team identifier matches the team identified in the code signature.
A constraint that matches if a process has the same team identifier as the calling process.
A constraint that tests whether a code file or running process is signed in a way that conforms to the specified validation category.
Supported Validation categories for signatures
A structure that represents the result of testing a lightweight code requirement.
Creates a constraint that requires code on disk to satisfy all of the provided constraints.
Creates a constraint that requires a launching process’s executable to satisfy all of the provided constraints.
Creates a constraint that requires a running process’s executable to satisfy all of the provided constraints.
Creates a constraint that requires a launching process’s executable to satisfy any of the provided constraints.
Creates a constraint that requires code on disk to satisfy any of the provided constraints.
Creates a constraint that requires a running process’s executable to satisfy any of the provided constraints.
A code object representing signed code running on the system.
A static code object representing signed code on disk.
The Core Foundation type representing a task.
Limit the libraries your process loads, and the situations where it runs.

abstract.text: Look inside a code signature to see how it uses hashes to protect the code’s executable pages, resources, and metadata from tampering.
An object that represents a subprocess of the current process.
Runs the process with the current environment.
The receiver’s executable.
